body: SecurityManagerLifecycleIntegrationTest failed due to changes in the PR.
LuceneClientSecurityWithRegionCreatedBeforeIndexDUnitTest and LuceneClientSecurityDUnitTest both failed, possibly due to changes in this PR.

> @metatype Thanks. I have updated CDDL to 1.1
> 
> Also `Checker Framework` seems to be GPL but I see that you considered it as BSD. Also GPL is _[category x](https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x)_ and not allowed.
> https://github.com/typetools/checker-framework/blob/master/LICENSE.txt

Whoops, I meant to add checker-qual under the MIT section.  If you look at their license statement [1], the qual/* and related files are under the more permissive MIT license.  You can also follow the discussion of this in the guava community [2].

[1] https://github.com/typetools/checker-framework/blob/master/LICENSE.txt
[2] https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/guava-discuss/wUmhhOP2Kpo

I would recommend not using forced push unless absolute necessary. So that we can keep a commit history, and see the diff of each commit when reviewing code. And also see the CI history of each commit. When we merge, we can squash all the commits into one.
@metatype I did fix the license for checker-qual. Do you want to take a final look at the changes and give a ðŸ‘ ?
@Petahhh
LGTM
LGTM, please commit and cherry-pick to release/1.9.0.  @sboorlagadda
Misunderstood the process for getting this to the release branch.  Closing to let it get cherry-picked from `develop`.

I separated GEODE-6562 and GEODE-6565 out to their own PRs.

InternalDistributedSystemBuilderIntegrationTest uses security which revealed a Shiro ThreadLocal leak when a Cache is not created (GEODE-6565) -- this caused MultipleCacheJUnitTest to fail when run later in the same JVM.

Fixing GEODE-6565 (Shiro ThreadLocal leak) caused LuceneClientSecurityDUnitTest and subclass to fail because a test was trying to use gemfire.properties that are incompatible with what's specified in getDistributedSystemProperties which is overridden in the super class.
Can we hold committing this until the benchmark optimization fix goes in so we can benchmark the result of this change?

I looked at the change set but couldn't follow the logic changes without spending more time.  It's looks like we're still using a Future, possibly created by a different thread right?  Could explain further?

Is this code used in `CacheLoader` situations as well?

> Can we hold committing this until the benchmark optimization fix goes in so we can benchmark the result of this change?

@pivotal-jbarrett yes we can. let me know once the benchmark fix is checked in.

> I looked at the change set but couldn't follow the logic changes without spending more time. It's looks like we're still using a Future, possibly created by a different thread right? Could explain further?
> 
> Is this code used in `CacheLoader` situations as well?

Separating the logical blocks is making the changes hard to read. The change avoids use of future for only proxy regions. For caching-proxy, it still uses the Futures. We had a discussion on this and agreed with this solution.

The CacheLoader invocation looked outside of this context. We have a failure in CacheLoader unit test, i am looking into it.
@sboorlagadda we need this change on release/1.9.0 also.

> @sboorlagadda we need this change on release/1.9.0 also.

Thanks. I will cherry-pick this once merged.
@Petahhh For your review
DistributedTest failure is an unrelated flaky failure in ClientServerTransactionFailoverDistributedTest
This PR is now ready for another round of reviews
Closing as duplicate
flaky test failure not related to this PR
LGTM

I have confirmed that both PR and RR's accessor need to add AEQ id. Otherwise the put operation will fail with GatewaySenderConfigurationException.

I added following 4 dunit tests:
1) PR accessor with AEQ id, so it will pass
2) PR accessor without AEQ id, it will throw exception.
3) RR accessor with AEQ id, so it will pass
4) RR accessor without AEQ id, it will throw exception.
DistributedTestOpenJDK8 failed due to known flaky test: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6462
@joeymcallister and @agingade please review
LGTM
Leaving Mockito at v0.23.x since later versions cause OOM in `HARegionQueueIntegrationTest`.
@metatype Iâ€™d ask that you open a JIRA to fix this test and upgrade Mockito.
A small drop in the ocean but a step forward no less. Would love some feedback on the changes. Eliminates most if not all the warnings in the IntelliJ analyzer gutter for these classes.
Also backing out the Jedis upgrade.
Could you please considered a different name like 'deprecated' that implies this shouldn't be used and may disappear at anytime.

It may cause connections that have been connected to a different server to move to the back of the queue. But since those connections have just been changed to a new server how active are they? No one has used them yet to send a message to their new server. Also we don't know where they were in the deque when we removed them. They could have been in the front, middle, or back. I would have preferred a solution that did not involve removing them but I think that would require bigger changes to the load conditioner and connection activation/passivation.

> @metatype Iâ€™d ask that you open a JIRA to fix this test and upgrade Mockito.

See GEODE-6590.

@davebarnes97 or @joeymcallister perhaps one of you could merge this (I cannot).

I think the JDK11 CI failure is ok given that this was a doc change and the failure is in a DUnit test.
The multipleClientLongTransactionsCanFailoverWithoutLosingOperations failure was also seen on another ci so it was not caused by this PR.
Test failures are unrelated to this change
Precheckin results are 100% GREEN.
failure unrelated to this change set
Thanks for the feedback. I have added time unit suffixes and 100ms of wiggle room
Using TimeUnit constants avoids confusion in math too. https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/TimeUnit.html
The dunit failure doesn't reproduce.  I ran the test 500 times with no problems.

@jinmeiliao: looks like a later commit to `develop` is generating some conflicts on this PR, will solve the conflicts locally, deprecate the old methods instead of directly rename them and squash the commits altogether to make the review easier. Cheers.
@Petahhh Please review
@Petahhh for your review
@Petahhh
@demery-pivotal  @mhansonp

This is not intended to be a real improvement, as we still have nonsensicle configuration of, for instance, `java-library` plugin being applied to non-Java subprojects.  The scope of this PR was intended to position each build.gradle to be reasonable independent of each other, so that the considerations about what each subproject *should* be can proceed relatively unfettered.
Also, despite the first commit claiming to have removed `ide.gradle`, that was the result of a mistaken initial branch.  Do note that the second-to-last commit reverts that removal.
I think the documentation page on this needs to be updated as well.  See https://geode.apache.org/docs/guide/18/topologies_and_comm/cs_configuration/client_server_whats_next.html.
@Petahhh
@davebarnes97 Can you please give the docs changes in https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3394/commits/14fcf3d5ec303482018e0e070ff36be4b7f674e5.
@Petahhh

@upthewaterspout That is a very good question. Is it better the it reflect the intent or reality. I think I would lean towards your suggestion of keeping track of the value but just ignoring it. This way the caller has its reality and we have ours. I will whip up a change. Thanks!
CI Failure in UpgradeTestOpenJDK11 is due to this known hang: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6407
@upthewaterspout We changed StoppableCountDownLatch to delegate to CountDownLatch instead of extending it and changed the ticket to "StoppableCountDownLatch should have unit tests"
@Petahhh For your review...
@Petahhh

I initially planned on adding a unit test to ProxyBucketRegionTest but it looked like ProxyBucketRegion would need to refactoring to get the advisor mockable. It uses a static method in the constructor to create the advisor and that static method is passed the partially constructed ProxyBucketRegion and uses some of its state to create the advisor. Since this is correcting a problem introduced by a refactoring that did not have tests, by undoing one of the changes, I think it is okay to not have test coverage for this pull request.
What part of this change actually makes the test not dependent on /etc/hosts? I see a lot of minor syntax changes, but it's kinda hard to see what behavior you actually changed?
The one failure: "PersistentRecoveryOrderDUnitTest > testCrashDuringPreparePersistentId" is a known issue that Kirk is fixing.
@Petahhh For your review
I''m going to split this into 2 PRs.
@Petahhh For your review.
The stress tests are going to fail until GEODE-6634 is merged

Will this potentially make the jobs run with more parallelism than we can handle? I think we sized things so that dunitParallelForks=24 will fill up the machine. If two jobs run in parallel, we will get weird failures now due to overprovisioning?

The lack of forkEvery=1 was intentional to make sure people introduced tests that cleaned up after themselves. But we keep running into confusion over this, so maybe accepting the new normal that tests don't clean up state is fine.

Currently, the jobs end up running with both `--parallel` and `--no-parallel` - just because of the way the scripts are written; I'm not sure which one gets precedence. With this change we can correctly select the option using the CI job parameters.

Perhaps the fix is elsewhere as I'm not quite sure exactly how `repeatTest` works. It shouldn't be spawning 1000's of JVMs though.
Hmmm, I think the test that I touched and triggered this change is really the culprit. I will investigate further...

Got it. I think we should make sure this job runs without parallel in the job parameters then - is that already the case or can you fix that as part of this change as well?

I'm ok with going to forkEvery=1, I just wanted to make sure you understood the history.

The last time I've seen gradle create 1000s of JVMs, it had something to do with the way gradle was scanning for matching tests (I created a new JVM for each potential test). So maybe something weird has happened or after some gradle upgrade we're back to scanning everything again.
@Petahhh
@Petahhh
@upthewaterspout Did you see the line (210) that Michael pointed out? That's the line that fixes the failure on Mac.
@Petahhh

@onichols-pivotal good point. Currently we are only doing basic filtering, like Id and group. which is just the attribute of CacheElement. That's why the list method only takes a CacheElement. later on, if we want to support more filtering attribute like (type or other attributes), we would need to introduce another construct to do so.
@Petahhh
Closing this out, without tests I don't think we can be confident in this move the old admin API.
When reviewing, focus on the changes in https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3450/commits/5ea16f374fc41f2cc2bf5fe89dd94d19a0e08d99. The other commit is cleanup before fixing.

@mivanac - Thanks for your contribution! May I suggest a slight wording change to your test's explanatory comment? "test for detect read conflicts" -> "test for detecting read conflicts".

stessNewTest failure is caused by the way the job is run, not the test iteself
@Petahhh

StressNewTest failed due to a suspect string. I'll have to review to see if it's ok and should be ignored or not.

org.apache.geode.internal.cache.persistence.PersistentRVVRecoveryDUnitTest > testLotsOfTombstones FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Suspicious strings were written to the log during this run.
    Fix the strings or use IgnoredException.addIgnoredException to ignore.
    -----------------------------------------------------------------------

    [fatal 2019/04/15 19:07:04.887 UTC <Replicate/Partition Region Garbage Collector> tid=262] GemFire garbage collection service encountered an unexpected exception
    org.apache.geode.cache.RegionDestroyedException: The DiskRegion has been closed or destroyed

    	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.DiskRegion.writeRVVGC(DiskRegion.java:826)

    	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.TombstoneService$ReplicateTombstoneSweeper.checkExpiredTombstoneGC(TombstoneService.java:640)

Since the maximum size of the byte array is limited to 64k we decided not the add the soft reference. This could be added in the future if we start using this cache for other things.

Hi,

thanks for the comments. I have applied them.

BR,
Mario
These are artifacts used in the tests. Hence no tests present for these classes

@moleske I think RegionDestroyedException is ok after the DiskStoreObserver test hook is triggered so I added an IgnoredException right after that. In general, it looks like TombstoneService.forceBatchExpirationForTests is not implemented very well and it could invoke later than expected. The comments in the code seem to indicate that it's not safe for the test to wait for it which I suspect might be due to one or more synchronizations blocking to wait for another thread that the test author wasn't quite sure about. Specifically TombstoneService.testHook_forceExpiredTombstoneGC looks a bit dodgy.
GatewayReceiverMetrics is never closed. AcceptorImpl should close it when it closes GatewayReceiverStats.
Unfortunately @pivotal-jbarrett and our team both cleaned up and then modified ServerConnection so this conflict is a doozy.

@upthewaterspout Unfortunately CacheServerImpl already contains GatewayReceiver logic in the form of the boolean so it was already tainted with poor design. I agree we should refactor this further. Eventually we should flip it around so that a GatewayReceiver (or InternalGatewayReceiver?) contains and uses a CacheServerImpl instead of passing it into CacheServerImpl. The GatewayReceiver would then create a GatewayReceiverAcceptor and pass that into CacheServerImpl as the Acceptor to be used. Mark and I were on the verge of tackling this but we felt that 2-3 more days of refactoring would be out of scope for one metric.

The discussion of stats vs metrics played out for weeks on our team. We definitely considered the approach that you're advocating but decided to go in the current direction. The mess known as CachePerfStats and RegionPerfStats provided much of the reason for this separation.

@demery-pivotal I prefer to submit multiple PRs for cleaning up and refactoring code in addition to adding new functionality. Others prefer this approach. I'll push harder for the separate PRs next time.

If you can, please focus on the commit for GEODE-6626: Add cache.gatewayreceiver.events.received counter and its fixup commit.

> Maybe it would be better to encapsulate the micrometer updates within GatewayReceiverStats. Or better yet, maybe within the Statistics interface itself? We could enhance StatisticsFactory to have a way to indicate which stats get sent to which micrometer meter. Or consider looking at how our JMX mbeans did things - you don't see any JMX related code in GatewayReceiverCommand, but the MBeans are also getting this same events received data!

If the stat already measures exactly the information we want to publish through the meter, that's a fine solution. Another possibility is to use a style of meter that fetches its values from the stat (using a Gauge, FunctionCounter, or FunctionTimer).

Sometimes the stat doesn't measure exactly the thing we want to publish through the meters. For example (from an earlier meter PR), some of the put-related measure internal details that are meaningful to developers, but measure something other than what an operator would expect them to mean. In those cases, we would have to instrument the meter separately from the stats.

Soâ€¦ if the intentions of a stat and a meter are to measure _**exactly**_ the same thing, yeah, let's take advantage of that.

> @demery-pivotal I prefer to submit multiple PRs for cleaning up and refactoring code in addition to adding new functionality. Others prefer this approach. I'll push harder for the separate PRs next time.

As a developer, I very much prefer cleaning up as I go. As a reviewer, I might have a different preference sometimes. In this case, it's possible that a more comprehensive description would have sufficed for me, so that I would have a clearer idea of the intention of the changes in each file.
@upthewaterspout I'll start a branch to separate CacheServerImpl and GatewayReceiver. Maybe we can follow up this PR with another that improves the design of CacheServerImpl.

> Sometimes the stat doesn't measure exactly the thing we want to publish through the meters. For example (from an earlier meter PR), some of the put-related measure internal details that are meaningful to developers, but measure something other than what an operator would expect them to mean. In those cases, we would have to instrument the meter separately from the stats.

It still makes more sense to have all of the stat updates go through a single consistent stat interface as far as the rest of the product is concerned. For the case of a stat that goes to micrometer but not VSD (why not just also send it to VSD, btw?) you could still add a method to GatewaySenderStats for that stat. Or StatisticsTypeFactory.createXXXCounter could in addition to taking a parameter indicating that something should go to micrometer, also indicate the stat doesn't need to go to VSD.

> Soâ€¦ if the intentions of a stat and a meter are to measure exactly the same thing, yeah, let's take advantage of that.

This should most of this micrometer work much easier and less error prone as well. Once you add some support in StatisticsFactory for micrometer, for any new stat that goes to micrometer you will just need to touch objects like GatewaySenderStats and add a flag or whatever during the statistics type creation indicating the stat should go to micrometer.

> (why not just also send it to VSD, btw?)

I believe that in general, when adding micrometer based metrics, we are not trying to change or enhance VSD based information.  The idea being that we will remove VSD once micrometer is providing all the metrics that VSD has.  This does not mean we couldn't add to VSD, but VSD is not tool of choice moving forward.

> Is there already a test for this?

Yes. Forgot that commit -a does not pick new file. Pushed the test file.
